grep_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
GREP : Used as a filter to get output based on a word hit/match
Usage: grep searchpattern filename
	grep -l searchpattern filename
--------------------------------------------------------------
cd_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
CD : Changes Directory
Usage: Cd - To change into home directory
Cd - To change into home directory~
Cd .. - To change into parent directory
Cd .. .. - To change into parent directory 2nd levelk
Cd directory/path - To change into a specifi directory
--------------------------------------------------------------
cp_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
CP : Copies content from one file to another
Usage: cp filename1 filename2
cp directory1/filename1 directory2/filename2
p filename1 dir/filename1
--------------------------------------------------------------
head_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
HEAD : Used to get first 10/given number of lines from files
Usage:  head filename (default 10 lines)
	head -n 20 filename - to get specific no of lines
	head -10 filename
--------------------------------------------------------------
tail_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
TAIL : Used to get first 10/given number of lines from files
Usage:  tail filename (default 10 lines)
	tail -n 20 filename - - to get specific no of lines
	tail -10 filename
--------------------------------------------------------------
wc_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
WC : Used to get number of lines,words,chars
Usage: wc filename (by default gives all three l,w,c)
wc -l : Gives just lines
wc -w : Gives just words
wc -c : Gives just chars
wc -l -w : Gives lines + chars
--------------------------------------------------------------
mkdir_man:
--------------------------------------------------------------
MKDIR : Used to make directories
Usage: mkdir dirname
mkdir -p dir1/dir2 : Create intermediate directories as required.
mkdir dir1 dir2
--------------------------------------------------------------
